context: Uncertainties about the effect of these factors may have implications for the performance of a qualitative test where the discriminatory capacity displays considerable sensitivity to the chosen threshold. The urea breath test exploits the presence of the urease enzyme, a characteristic feature of H. pylori. Labeled urea is ingested by the patient who then exhales into an appropriate container for subsequent analysis of breath. In the 13C-urea breath test, an enrichment in the 13CO2/12CO2ratio over a baseline (pre-drink) sample is consistent with H. pylori infection (7–9). The principal differences among reported 13C-urea breath tests center on the amount of 13C-urea used and the type or presence of a test meal. In fact, there has been considerable discussion in the literature over the optimal format of the 13C-urea breath test in an attempt to standardize the test (10,11). For instance, it has been suggested that factors such as test meal composition and prior versus concurrent ingestion of citric acid (relative to labeled urea), are of relevance to the rate of gastric emptying and, by extension, to the residence time of urea in the stomach.
